skill.name: vue-best-practices
skill.description: Vue 3 and Vue.js best practices for TypeScript, vue-tsc, and Volar. This skill should be used when writing, reviewing, or refactoring Vue components to ensure correct typing patterns. Triggers on tasks involving Vue components, props extraction, wrapper components, template type checking, or Volar configuration.

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing Vue.js best practices. Static findings are false positives caused by the scanner misidentifying markdown code fences (backticks) as Ruby shell execution and documentation links as hardcoded URLs. No executable code exists in this skill.

medium_findings.title: Markdown Code Fences Misidentified as Shell Commands
medium_findings.description: The static scanner flagged backtick characters in markdown code blocks as 'Ruby/shell backtick execution'. This is a false positive - the backticks are markdown syntax for code fences, not executable shell commands.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: All flagged locations are markdown code fences containing example Vue/TypeScript code. The backticks are syntax for markdown code blocks, not Ruby shell execution.

medium_findings.title: Documentation Links Misidentified as Hardcoded URLs
medium_findings.description: The static scanner flagged URL references in documentation as 'Hardcoded URL'. These are legitimate external resource links in markdown files, not runtime network requests.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: All URLs are reference links in markdown documentation for Vue.js resources. The skill makes no runtime network calls.

low_findings.title: Path Traversal Patterns in Documentation Examples
low_findings.description: The scanner detected path traversal sequences (../) in markdown files. These are relative path references to other documentation files within the skill, not filesystem operations.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Path references are markdown links to other rule files in the documentation structure.

content.value_statement: Vue 3 projects often have type errors and configuration issues that are hard to debug manually. This skill provides automated linting rules and fixes for Vue component typing, Volar configuration, vue-tsc strict templates, and common Vue.js patterns.
actual_capabilities: Extract TypeScript types from Vue component props using vue-component-type-helpers
Fix template type checking errors with vue-tsc strictTemplates
Type-check fallthrough attributes in wrapper components
Detect CSS module class typos before runtime
Configure Volar 3.0 breaking changes and compatibility settings
limitations: Does not modify project files directly - provides guidance and code examples only
Does not install or configure npm packages
Does not run Vue or TypeScript compilation
Cannot fix build system or bundler configuration issues

output_examples.input: How do I extract the type of props from a child Vue component?
My CSS modules are not catching typos in class names
output: Enable strict CSS modules in tsconfig:
This will cause TypeScript errors when you use a class name that doesn't exist in your .module.css file.

output: This allows any attribute starting with "data-" to pass type checking.

best_practices: Use ComponentProps from vue-component-type-helpers instead of manual type extraction for wrapper components
Enable strictTemplates in vue-tsc to catch template type errors during development
Configure Volar 3.0 with vueCompilerOptions.target set to 3 for Vue 3.5+ compatibility
anti_patterns: Using manual type intersections for props instead of vue-component-type-helpers
Ignoring template type errors instead of fixing the underlying type issues
Not configuring dataAttributes when using custom data-* attributes in templates

faq.question: What is the difference between vue-tsc and Volar?
faq.answer: Volar is the VSCode extension that provides language support for Vue. vue-tsc is the TypeScript compiler wrapper that runs Volar's type checking from the command line. They share the same underlying type checking logic.

faq.question: How do I fix 'Cannot find module' errors in Vue projects?
faq.answer: Ensure your tsconfig.json includes @vue/tsconfig and that your moduleResolution is set to 'bundler'. Add paths to tsconfig.json if using path aliases like @/ or ~/.

faq.question: Can this skill modify my project files?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides guidance, code examples, and explains best practices. It does not modify your project files directly.

faq.question: What Vue versions are supported?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on Vue 3 with TypeScript, including Vue 3.5+ features like defineModel, deep watch arrays, and improved reactivity typing.

faq.question: How do I type Vue Router route parameters?
faq.answer: Use typed-router plugins like unplugin-vue-router or vue-router's typed APIs. Configure your router to export RouteRecordRaw with proper param types.

faq.question: Does this skill work with Nuxt?
faq.answer: Some rules apply to Nuxt projects, particularly around TypeScript configuration. However, Nuxt has its own module system that may require different approaches.
